image.altText: A woman looks sternly at the camera.

props.synopsis: Crystal's baby was born in jail while she waited for her case to be processed. Her wait for justice is not uncommon in the NT, where the courts are so backlogged that unprecedented numbers of people are being left to languish on remand.

title.children: Crystal had her baby in prison while on remand, stuck in an NT corrections system 'at breaking point'

image.altText: Three men address the media.

props.synopsis: The NT government has revealed plans to permanently transfer children from Alice Springs youth detention to Darwin as part of an "emergency response" aimed at rolling out a thousand new prison beds over the next four years.

title.children: Alice Springs youth to be relocated to Darwin as part of NT government's 'emergency' prisons plan

image.altText: A black-and-white photo of a young boy leaning on the railing of a rodeo arena.

props.synopsis: The cost of living and a downturn in ticket sales have led to the collapse of the board that runs the famed Mount Isa rodeo.

title.children: Cost of living blamed as largest rodeo in the southern hemisphere enters voluntary administration

image.altText: Man in orange basketball singlet lays up shot

props.synopsis:
The Darwin Salties have become just the latest NT sports club to bite the dust, after quitting the NBL1 North basketball competition for financial reasons. It comes as the NT continues its push to join the AFL.

Â

title.children: What the demise of a popular Darwin basketball club could mean for the NT's AFL team bid

image.altText: Gwilym Lee, Miranda Tapsell and Gladys-May Kelly in character sitting outside on rocks by the water with arms around each other

props.synopsis: Top End Bub is a follow-up to the 2019 smash-hit film Top End Wedding. But instead of another movie, its creators have opted for a TV series. Co-creator, executive producer and star Miranda Tapsell explains why as first look images of the series are released.

title.children: Miranda Tapsell grew up wanting the lifestyle Hollywood presented until she realised her upbringing was idyllic

image.altText: an old car wreck on a dirt road

props.synopsis: A driving school in WA's north is doing its best to reduce Indigenous road deaths, by removing the financial barriers that often prevent people learning to drive safely.

title.children: First Nations people are more likely to die on the roads, but this regional driving school hopes to change that

image.altText: A child walks down a red dirt road in front of a rain-soaked Uluru.

props.synopsis: Tourism operators are calling on Parks Australia to urgently upgrade the Uluru base walk to an all-weather track, after years of intermittent rain closures hurting local businesses.

title.children: Uluru track closures in wet weather costing tourism operators at Australia's 'crown jewel'

image.altText: The exterior of the Alice Springs Local Court building.

props.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a toddler, who fell into a septic tank in a remote Central Australian community last year, has heard about a string of departmental failures to address safety risks at the site.

title.children: Inquest into toddler's septic tank death hears infrastructure department 'ignored' safety risks

image.altText: Two women wearing sports singlets, sunglasses and sun visors high fiving while standing in the bush.

props.synopsis: It's been six years since the Masters Games were last held in Alice Springs. The event returned this year with lower numbers, but fans hope it will come back stronger.

title.children: Alice Springs locals say Masters Games has brought 'magic' back to the town

props.synopsis:
Politicians on both sides of parliament attack Lidia Thorpe's disruption of a ceremony for King Charles. But on Q+A, one Indigenous man urged them to listen.

Â 

Â

title.children: 'What do we have left?' Indigenous plea to listen to Lidia Thorpe

image.altText: A microchip.

props.synopsis: Silicon chips are now fundamental to modern life, incorporated into every facet of electronics and driving up share prices on Wall Street. Taiwan has dominated semiconductor production but finds itself at the centre of a geopolitical, and technological, contest.

title.children: Taiwan's chip domination the real prize in East-West divide

image.altText: Emissions are seen from a factory at Broadwater in far northern New South Wales.

props.synopsis: The federal government may push back the release of its 2035 emissions reduction target from early next year.

title.children: Australia's next big climate target might be delayed by months

image.altText: Jill Stein speaks at a podium.

props.synopsis: The Biden administration's staunch support of Israel was already threatening the Democrats' support from Arab-Americans in the key battleground state of Michigan, but for some in the community the escalating situation in Lebanon is the final straw.

title.children: In one attack ad, Jill Stein's face morphs into Donald Trump. This is why she's a target

image.altText: Peter Dutton wears glasses and looks up while sitting in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The differences between Labor and the Coalition's plans to ease the housing crisis are becoming clearer, with the opposition betting that Australians prefer detached dwellings in outer suburbs rather than high-density housing.Â

title.children: The opposition is betting on detached homes in outer suburbs as the election fight over housing policies shapes up

image.altText: A sparse new kitchen, with blue cupboards , white bench top, polished concrete floor and wooden shelving.

props.synopsis: Rebuilding a home exactly as it was doesn't always make sense for those impacted by natural disasters. Queensland is helping home-owners retrofit to be more resilient.

title.children: More Australians are retrofitting their homes to be natural disaster 'proof'. Here's what they're doing

image.altText: A Qantas worker wearing a high-vis vest wipes down an engine that has a red kangaroo logo on it.

props.synopsis: After Qantas was ordered by the Federal Court to compensate 1,700 former workers, an industrial relations lawyer says the airline will still have saved millions of dollars once it pays its legal bills, ex-employees, and any extra penalties.

title.children: Qantas saved $580m by sacking hundreds of ground crew. They won't get anything close to that in compensation

image.altText: A front on head and shoulders shot of  man in a suit with a blurred green background.

props.synopsis: All the posts have been deleted or had their viewing permissions changed since the ABC put questions to the party and each candidate.

title.children: One Nation candidates are posting conspiracy theories about QAnon and man-made storms on social media

image.altText: Portrait of Shane Rattenbury sitting on a small wall with bushland down a mountain behind him.

props.synopsis: The ACT election saw the Greens go from six seats in the Legislative Assembly to three, with a fourth possible, but the swing against them was smaller than it appeared with the result being the party's third-best in ACT history.

title.children: ACT Greens still have 'very strong base' despite losing nearly half their Legislative Assembly seats

image.altText: Leaupepe Lasa Aiono wearing a yellow bandana on head looking at camera whilst holding two Chinese cabbages in hands.

props.synopsis: One of the key themes for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting this week is "a resilient environment" â and King Charles has long promoted climate change mitigation.

title.children: When King Charles feasts on Samoan produce, farmers hope he remembers their greatest threat: climate change

image.altText: A view of a harbour in Jeju Island in South Korea

props.synopsis: The South Korean island of Jeju is offering newlyweds the chance to rent apartments for less than $30 a month in the hope it might encourage them to have children.

title.children: South Korean tourism island offers rent for $28 a month to boost fertility rates

image.altText: A man in a black t-shirt and cap stands behind a bar with bottles of alcohol all around him

props.synopsis: Darren Brown says he has gone to "every length" to get the hotel he runs properly listed on Google, and that without the visibility the losses to the business have been "immeasurable".

title.children: 'Basically invisible': Pub's lengthy battle to be listed on Google

image.altText: Back of person's head wearing a computer headset and using computer.

props.synopsis: The National Anti-Scam Centre is warning people to be wary of calls supposedly coming from their bank, urging them to be on guard for fraudsters.Â

title.children: Getting calls from your bank? It could be a scammer

image.altText: A man is tackled in a rugby league match

props.synopsis: The last time Australia met New Zealand, the Kangaroos suffered the heaviest defeat in their history. This weekend, they'll be out for revenge when the two sides meet in Christchurch.

title.children: Australia looking to avenge heaviest defeat in 116 years ahead of clash with New Zealand

image.altText: An aerial view of a retirement village surrounded by a body of water. The buildings have matching grey rooves.

props.synopsis: Retirement villages are governed by a patchwork of laws that differ from state to state but advocates want tougher regulation of the sector. Could treating the sector like a "financial product" be the answer, and how would it work?

title.children: Should retirement villages be treated like 'financial products'?

image.altText: Close-up of Neil Finn talking on episode of Take 5 with Zan Rowe

props.synopsis: Neil Finn joins Zan Rowe on Take 5 to share how his never-ending compulsion to create has been inspired by Fleetwood Mac and his father's love of jazz.

title.children: Neil Finn's music has soundtracked our lives. But what has soundtracked his?

image.altText: Moldova's President Maia Sandu casts her vote during Moldova's presidential election and EU referendum.

props.synopsis: Moldovans have voted by a razor-thin majority in favour of securing the country's path toward European Union membership, electoral data shows.Â

title.children: Moldova narrowly votes for EU membership amid claims of 'unprecedented' Russian interference

image.altText: Wide road with cars and trucks

props.synopsis: An inquest into the death of a Shellharbour man restrained by police on Sydney's M5 has revealed critical shortcomings in CPR training for officers. The coroner has called for urgent reforms to improve police responses.

title.children: NSW coroner identifies critical police CPR training gaps after fatal Sydney M5 encounter

image.altText: Two boys sit on a makeshift white scrap of sheet in front of a port.

props.synopsis: Escalating militant attacks on Chinese investments threaten China's Belt and Road initiative in Pakistan as security concerns dominate talks between the two countries.Â

title.children: China's 'Silk Road' ambitions threatened by militant attacks

image.altText: A woman in red swimsuit

props.synopsis: An Italian surfer has died in a rare and tragic accident after being struck by a swordfish while surfing off Indonesia's West Sumatra coast.

title.children: Surfer dies in freak swordfish accident while catching wave off west coast of Sumatra

image.altText: A woman and man with sunglasses.

props.synopsis: It was alleged two boys â who cannot be identified as they were 17 years old at the time â broke into the Lovell's house on Boxing Day night in 2022.

title.children: Husband of Brisbane woman killed during home invasion didn't realise he had also been stabbed, court hears

image.altText: A blindfolded woman wearing an aqua shirt holds a tennis racquet, in the process of returning a serve.

props.synopsis: Australia has a rich blind tennis history but has historically struggled to attract players with no vision at all. Tess Whelan is Australia's first international B1 competitor and is hoping to pave the way for more to come.

title.children: How Australia's first international blindfolded tennis star is changing the game

image.altText: A wrinkly cat sits on a lap

props.synopsis: The XL Bully cat, a crossbreed of Sphynx cats and Munchkin cats, is causing global concern due to its rising popularity.Â

title.children: 'An animal welfare disaster': The designer cat breed causing international concern

image.altText: An elderly man wearing a blue shirt and dark suit jacket stands next to a painting with calligraphic text

props.synopsis: Influential cleric Fethullah GÃ¼len, known for starting the faith movement Hizmet in 1969 and blamed for a failed coup against Turkish leader ErdoÄan, dies in the US aged 83.

title.children: Fethullah GÃ¼len, cleric accused of 2016 TÃ¼rkiye coup attempt, dies aged 83

image.altText: A general shot of work taking place at a mine site.

props.synopsis: Companies have been charged over the deaths of workers in separate incidents in the Pilbara and the Goldfields in 2022.

title.children: Worksafe to prosecute mining companies after deaths at WA sites just days apart

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding a glass under a running tap, filling it with water

props.synopsis: The National Health and Medical Research Council has released draft guidelines on limits for four types of "forever chemicals" in drinking water. So how do they compare with other countries such as the US?

title.children: Draft limits of PFAS in Australia's drinking water released by national medical research body
